description:
Actinemys marmorata, commonly known as the western pond turtle or Pacific pond turtle, is a species of freshwater turtle native to the western United States and Canada. It belongs to the family Emydidae, a group of pond and river turtles.

Actinemys marmorata is a medium-sized turtle, with a carapace (upper shell) that typically ranges from 12 to 20 centimeters (4.7 to 7.9 inches) in length. The carapace is oval-shaped and has a domed or flattened appearance, with a brown, olive, or black coloration often mottled or patterned. The plastron (lower shell) is yellow or tan, sometimes with dark blotches or markings.

These turtles are semi-aquatic, spending much of their time in slow-moving freshwater habitats such as ponds, lakes, marshes, and streams. They are opportunistic omnivores, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, insects, small fish, and carrion. Actinemys marmorata is an important component of the ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey species.

Actinemys marmorata is considered a species of conservation concern in parts of its range due to factors such as habitat loss, pollution, and human-related impacts. Efforts to protect and conserve this species involve habitat restoration, population monitoring, and educational outreach.
